awd_titl_txt: Disentangling the roles of mutation and selection in the evolution of host-repression of transposable elements
awd_abstract_narration:
Transposable elements (TEs) are parasites that are found in the DNA of almost all organisms. They are considered to be selfish genetic elements because they use host machinery to make copies of themselves and then manage to get these copies pasted around the host's genome. Because TEs are transmitted from parent to offspring, they play an important role in genome evolution. They dramatically expand the size of genomes, rearrange DNA within and among chromosomes, and modify the activity of individual genes.  However, TE infection also harms the host by mutating, disrupting, and disorganizing DNA. As a consequence, TE movement can cause host sterility and is associated with the onset and progression of multiple cancers. Teasing apart the mechanisms of TE regulation, therefore, is of fundamental importance for human health. Additionally, the fertility costs of TE infection presents a potential strategy for biological control of disease vectors, agricultural pests, and invasive species. However, we know virtually nothing about how TEs adapt or evolve within a host or how a host evolves in response to TE invasion. This research project takes advantage of a new TE invasion into an experimental line of fruit flies and allows for an unprecendented exploration into the evolutionary interactions between a transposable element and a host.


Despite the manifold impact of TEs on their hosts, our understanding of how the host-genome responds to infection remains extremely limited. This research will use the well-characterized historical invasion of the Drosophila melanogaster genome by the P-element DNA transposon as a model to examine the evolution of host repression. The recent occurrence of this invasion, as well as the preservation of ancestral genetic variation in laboratory strains, provides an unparalleled opportunity to examine host repression at the three most critical time points: just before invasion, during invasion, and just after invasion. It also provides the opportunity to deconstruct this evolutionary process in the laboratory and to interpret outcomes in natural populations. Specifically, this project will: 1) Characterize standing genetic variation in permissiveness of P-element transposition in a genetic model of the ancestral D. melanogaster population (just before invasion); 2) Define the mutational and selective processes that lead to the evolution of repression during invasion of experimental populations by transpositionally active P-elements; 3) Uncover the contributions of standing genetic variation, de novo mutation, and selection to the evolution of host repression in extant natural populations (just after invasion).

por.por_cntn:
Transposable elements, also known as jumping genes, spread through host genomes by introducing new copies of themselves into new chromosomal sites. While some types of transposable elements can be domesticated to perform functions for their host cell, they are initially selfish genetic parasites that harm their host by causing DNA damage and mutation. While their spread is generally opposed by host regulatory mechanisms, transposable elements are found in all genomes and comprise the major fraction of many genomes.

Transposable elements are transmitted from parent to offspring through chromosomes; however, they occasionally invade the genome of a new distantly-related species. After invasion by a novel transposable element, a host genome is challenged to tolerate the proliferation of the invading element and evolve mechanisms to control its spread. To study these processes, we took advantage of the recent invasion of the fruit fly (Drosophila melanogaster) genome by P transposable elements, which occurred in the 1950's. Because this invasion occurred very recently, there is a historical record of the invasion into natural populations worldwide. Additionally, numerous laboratory strains were collected before the invasion, which empowers us to identify genetic changes that occurred in D. melanogaster after the TE invaded.

            We discovered that the D. melanogaster host rapidly evolved control of the invading P-elements through a novel, mutation-driven process. Specifically, as the P-elements spread to more and more chromosomal sites around the genome, they disproportionately came to occupy chromosomal sites that produce regulatory small RNAs (Figure 1). Regulatory small RNAs derived from transposable elements are known to reduce their proliferation. The accumulation of P-elements in small RNA producing sites therefore ensured the evolution of host control, without any apparent requirement for natural selection. This mode of evolution provides a stark contrast to most examples of rapidly evolved traits, in which positive selection acts on a small number of new beneficial mutations to drive evolutionary changes in natural populations. This mutation dependent process is mostly likely the general mechanism through which host control of invading transposable elements evolves, since the basic architecture of host regulation through small RNAs is ubiquitous in plants and animals.

            We also asked whether there are individual differences in the ability of the host fly to tolerate the spread of transposable elements to new chromosomal sites. Because transposable elements are transmitted from parent to offspring through chromosomes, they must make new chromosomal copies in sperm or eggs. This process can damage chromosomes and reduce fertility. We discovered genetic differences in the ability of a female fly to avoid fertility effects resulting from P-element proliferation. We furthermore genetically mapped these differences to particular regions of the D. melanogaster genome (Figure 2). Our ongoing analysis of the genes underlying tolerance suggests that developmental regulators of gamete formation, as well as DNA repair machinery, may both be important in determining tolerance.

            Our research provided training for undergraduate and graduate students as well as local 7th grade science teachers. 3 Ph.D. dissertations resulted from this funding. A total of 21 undergraduates, including 11 women and 11 individuals from underrepresented groups contributed to this research, and 7 of these individuals were co-authors on published papers or submitted manuscripts. Finally, 4 local seventh grade science teachers participated in this research, with one being a co-author on a published paper.

            This award also served to improve science education in the greater Houston area. The award provided training for a genetics education workshop for 7th grade science teachers, which was attended by >60 local science teachers over 4 years. These teachers brought what they learned back to their classrooms, impacting up to 7,500 7th grade science students annually. Houston consistently ranks among the most diverse major metropolitan areas in the U.S.. with sizeable fractions of underrepresented minority, economically disadvantaged and at-risk students. This award therefore impacted a body of students who stand to benefit the most from increased investment in education. Beyond the workshops, 3 lesson plans were developed for 7th grade science classrooms, which use fruit flies as a model to teach basic concepts in inheritance and genetics in an engaging and inquiry-based manner.
